conclusion: The number of molecules colliding with the unit area of the wall per unit time is directly related to the pressure of the gas.
In the P-V diagram, the pressure is represented by the vertical axis (P).
From state C to state D, the process is isothermal, meaning the temperature remains constant.
The volume decreases as the gas moves from state C to state D.
Since the temperature is constant during an isothermal process, the ideal gas law (PV = nRT) indicates that the product of pressure and volume remains constant.
As the volume decreases from state C to state D, the pressure must increase to maintain the constant product of pressure and volume.
Since the pressure increases from state C to state D, the number of molecules colliding with the unit area of the wall per unit time also increases.
Therefore, the number of molecules colliding with the unit area of the wall per unit time increases from state C to state D.
